title: Will Daniel Ortega cease to be the president of Nicaragua before 11 January 2022?
preds: At this time (January 9, 2022), there appears to be no indication that Daniel Ortega or his wife, Vice-President Rosario Murillo, will step down. On the contrary, they appear be standing their ground. Yesterday, on January 8, 2022, The Confidencial reported: "In her first daily discourse of 2022, first lady and vice president Rosario Murillo declared that the inauguration ceremony would take place in Managua’s Plaza of the Revolution. 'We’ll all take the oath, the oath of the people’s presidency,' she expounded." Further, the opposition's plan appears to be a civil one, as opposed to something resembling a coup. Civil action takes time to develop and transpire, leaving little room for anything substantial to happen in the next 48 hours. The only conceivable thwart to Ortega's taking the oath and serving as President in the next few days would appear at this time to be something extreme and drastic, such as nationwide rioting, looting, and violence (unlikely, given the opposition's admonition to the populace to stay home), or an assassination attempt on Ortega's life. While such an attempt on his life is not entirely out of the question, its success seems unlikely, given the extra precautions and protection his regime will likely be making at the moment, in light of all the unrest. President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua was assassinated in 1980, but he was in exile in Paraguay at the time, and in any event a single case is not enough to use to make a prediction about Ortega's future. There are plenty of documented assassination attempts on Fidel Castro, but the comparison is not  quite apropos; he was a different leader in a different country in a very different period of history. Conclusion: Barring a fluke event, there is almost no chance that Daniel Ortega ceases to be the president of Nicaragua by 11 January 2022.
He is ensconced and it will take months of protest if they ever start.

Ortega recently seized the Taiwan embassy in Nicaragua to give it to China (who is opening their first embassy there since 1990) and strengthened ties with Russia sending a mission led by his two sons to discuss investments and economic cooperation in early December. 
His government continues to deny there is a Covid crisis and has violated the transparency agreements it had agreed to in order to obtain a $185.4 million in loans to address the pandemic which it received the IMF, the World Bank and the InterAmerican Development Bank.  A CID Gallup poll on the Dec 13 concluded Ortega received 27% of the vote not 76% as he had claimed to have received in November 7 election. With his main opponent in prison, he ran uncontested or a 4th term. While some see Ortega as growing increasingly isolated from the international community, he seems to be getting stronger with an effectively maimed opposition

https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210921-amid-official-denials-nicaraguans-battle-covid-surge
Not through any normal means. And the probability of an extra-ordinary event is essentially zero, practically speaking.
Ousting Ortega when it happens will be a long and bloody process that may take years.

2 recent voter suppression laws enacted (Foreign Agents law, Special Cybercrimes Law) and persons labeled as terrorists or traitors cannot run or hold office. All branches of legislation are held by Ortega's party, there are no term limits, and winner needs a simple plurality of votes. The 2016 election was marred with political moves to limit Ortega's opposition power and ability to run for office. Information from Freedom House https://freedomhouse.org/country/nicaragua/freedom-world/2021
Expainex in preev Expaind  in previos forecast.

Some sort of loose knit crew could make some noise regarding the rotten politics. Considering that Ortega family is has gained the cult of peronality not unlike the Somozas or Stroessners. Ticket for Kremlin interests next year. Since Nic is not getting the attention from US and other allìes it  thinks it  deserves

https://www.entornointeligente.com/nicaragua-se-acerca-peligrosamente-a-una-dictadura/ https://gaceta.es/gaceta-tv/estamos-llegando-al-limite-de-lo-que-podemos-hacer-para-enfrentar-a-ortega-20210622-0700/ https://www.confidencial.com.ni/politica/las-razones-de-los-paises-caribenos-de-la-oea-para-dar-la-espalda-a-ortega/ The current situation regarding foreign politics and current local conditions , being understood that there is no current party that can outstand Ortega, means chances to cease are almost non existent.
No indication that Ortega is in any trouble of losing power.  He has a solid grip on power.

Recent electoral reforms do not guarantee transparent, fair and free elections; on the contrary, they incorporate new causes to inhibit candidates. Furthermore, the electoral institution, despite recent changes, continues to be dominated by the FSLN.
https://www.confidencial.com.ni/politica/opositores-lamentan-que-regimen-desperdicia-una-salida-a-la-crisis-sociopolitica/

The groups opposed to the Ortega government are still not united, until today everything indicates that they will go to elections separately, which disperses the vote and limits the possibilities of a victory. 
https://www.confidencial.com.ni/politica/reunion-entre-cxl-y-prd-continua-en-el-limbo/
https://www.confidencial.com.ni/politica/kitty-monterrey-no-hablemos-de-dos-bloques-sino-de-una-opcion-y-esperamos-ser-nosotros/
The government continues without carrying out the necessary electoral reforms to guarantee free and transparent elections. https://www.confidencial.com.ni/politica/gabriel-alvarez-recomienda-a-la-oposicion-proponer-cambios-de-magistrados-en-el-cse/
However, unlike 5 or 6 months ago, the different opposition coalitions are a little more organized (definition of the mechanism for the selection of candidates).

How Ortega can cease to be the president of Nicaragua before 11 Jan 2021 A.	General elections. It is very questionable if the elections on 7 Nov 2021 will be free and fair, and if Ortega will resign if he were to lose. Still there could be certain momentum initiated around the elections that could become Ortega’s downfall. Likelihood ~5%.  B.	Death/ sickness. Due to Ortega being above the national life expectancy and having known health issue there is a possibility of him dying or becoming incapicated before 11 Jan 2022. Likelihood ~5%.  C.	Foreign military intervention. A foreign military intervention in Nicaragua is not on the table. Especially not with the Biden administration in the White house. Likelihood <1%.  D.	Coup d’etat. In 2018 Nicaragua experienced nationwide protests and a dynamic emerged where a coup could have taken place. This did not happen though, and the Ortega regime has since made sure to promote loyalists within the armed forces. Likelihood 1%.  E.	Steps down voluntary. Ortega could have stepped down voluntarily during the protests a few years ago, or when his presidential term limit reached its end the first time. Likelihood 1%.  F.	Impeachment. It is unclear whether something similar to impeachment exists in Nicaragua, it has been calls for impeachment in the past though. Due to Ortega’s control of the parliament (71 out of 92 members belongs to his party) it is very unlikely that any impeachment attempts would be successful now.  Things could thoretically change after the elections in November though if he wins the presidency but loses the parliament. Likelihood 1%.  Alternatives A-F add up to a 13% likelihood that Ortega will cease to be the president of Nicaragua before 11 January 2022. Factors to keep an eye on is how the general election turns out, the Covid-19 situation and the loyalty of the security forces. References

Daniel Ortega has been in power since he won the elections in 2006. He managed to get a Supreme Court ruling allowing him to be re-elected. The authorities of the State are monopolized by his party (FSLN). One of them is the Supreme Electoral Council, whose system needs profound reforms to guarantee free, fair and transparent elections. So far, 9 months before the November elections, the government has shown no signs of willingness to guarantee the conditions that would allow the opposition to participate in elections; on the contrary, in the last six months the legislature has approved a series of laws that seek to limit the political participation of organizations and parties and to disqualify opposition candidates. In addition, there remains a constant siege against opposition leaders. Added to this is the lack of consensus and unity of the opposition groups.
Ortega could agree to certain technical reforms, but without sufficiently leveling the ground for the opposition.
Ortega's latest onslaught against the business sector, the only sector with which he has sat down to negotiate in the past and now seeks to weaken it, must be taken into account.
However, taking into account that there is pressure from the international community (governments and multilateral organizations) for electoral reforms; that 70% of the population (Cid Gallup, January 2021) does not have a political party of preference and that the opposition still has a chance to reach an agreement, I give a 15% probability.

going up and over the crowd. only one reason, health/age risk doesn't reflect crowd bet. Over the years, Ortega has suffered two heart attacks and developed high cholesterol and other ailments, an official told Reuters last week. Since then, the president has been increasingly protective of his health, the official said.
He’s 75 and not in best shape. If anything happens to him, his wife (VP) steps in. He’ll win any election thanks to corruption. Still 1% based on his consuming bad Gallo Pinto.

From the referenced CFR article:
“...so any election that takes place won’t be free and fair.”

The economy is in deep recession, response to the Covid pandemic has been woeful but, Ortega holds control of all the key government institutions and is repressing any opposition, journalists or the media. Nicaragua has shown a resilience to ignore International pressure that gives a possible nervous rationale to increase the repression by passing laws claiming all opposition to be  traitors and terrorists.
Ortega’s Sandinista party gained a 79% majority in Congress allowing him total control over the army, police, rule by decree and to run for election indefinitely. 
In a country with a population of 6.6 million, 100,000 citizens and about 90 journalists have fled Nicaragua for surrounding countries and the opposition is divided.
Therefore, only a coup is likely to remove him), so probably unlikely. https://nearshoreamericas.com/nicaragua-ortega-gains-sweeping-powers-to-declare-political-rivals-terrorists/  http://country.eiu.com/Default.aspx?country=Nicaragua  https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/trend-lines/29158/repressive-new-laws-in-nicaragua-reveal-ortega-s-growing-insecurity  https://www.envio.org.ni/articulo/3480 https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2020/mar/11/over-100000-have-fled-nicaragua-since-brutal-2018-crackdown-says-un  https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/07/27/sustained-pressure-against-ortega-government
The kind of regime stablished by Daniel can change at any time.

"Ortega’s Sandinista National Liberation Front (FSLN) controls the legislature, judiciary, and much of the media in Nicaragua, but he is not leaving his electoral hopes to chance. He has ratcheted up his crack down on political dissent and intensified his efforts to limit free speech. Just this week the National Assembly passed a law empowering Ortega, who also ran Nicaragua from 1979 to 1990, to ban opposition candidates from running. So any election that takes place won’t be free and fair."
So, he'll win.
He’s following the Putin strong man model. Unlikely. Plus his family is getting rich while he’s in power. Unaware of any real competition. No Nicaraguan Navalny’s.
